I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed debt 
investment in bonds of up to B5,000,000,000 (or its equivalent in United States dollars) to be 
issued by B.Grimm Power Public Company Limited (B.Grimm) for the Thailand Green Bond 
Project. 
 
2.  The project entails the construction and refinancing of 16 solar power plants in Thailand, 
for a total of 98.5 megawatts (MW). B.Grimm will issue corporate bonds to finance these solar 
assets.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  subscribe  to  the  bonds  subject  to  their 
recognition as green bonds in compliance with the International Capital Markets Association's 
Green Bond Principles (GBP), which ADB will facilitate. ADB will also assist B.Grimm with its 
application to the Climate Bond Initiative (CBI) for the bonds to be certified as climate bonds under 
its Climate Bond Standards (CBS). ADB’s participation is crucial for GBP compliance and CBI 
certification, and the project will contribute to the development of the green bond market in 
Thailand and the region because these will be the first GBP-compliant green bonds issued by an 
energy company, and the first CBI-certified climate bonds in Thailand. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. The finance sector worldwide is beginning to respond to global 
warming and climate change, and joining the collective efforts to tackle these unprecedented 
challenges by mainstreaming climate mitigation and adaptation in its investment decisions. An 
increasing number of institutional investors and banks have begun to “decarbonize”, i.e., suspend 
new investment in and lending to coal- and other fossil-fuel-related companies and projects, and 
also divest themselves from such exposures in their existing portfolios.1 This also means that 
more and more institutional investors are prioritizing and favoring investments in renewable 
energy and climate change mitigation/adaptation, and looking for credible and verifiable means 
to evidence  it.  They need to  assure their clients, shareholders, and  other stakeholders of 
transparency and accountability, and to demonstrate that they are responsible investors. This 
transition is equally important for project developers and other issuers because any companies 
and projects with significant greenhouse gas emissions can be penalized in the capital markets, 
whereas evidence of climate-friendly investments can result in favorable financing terms. 
 
4.  Green bonds are innovative financial instruments to promote such efforts, whereby the 
proceeds are used exclusively to finance or refinance, in part or in full, new or existing green 
projects with environmental or climate-related benefits. The GBP and CBS are the two most well-
recognized standards of green bonds based on international best practice, while there are other 
standards as well as “self-declared” green bonds.2 Green bonds serve as a vehicle for financing 
investments in green and climate-smart projects that contribute to the achievement of a low-
carbon future under the Paris Agreement on climate change and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable 
Development of the United Nations. The green bond market is growing rapidly and reached an 
annual issuance amount of $173 billion in 2017 globally, from just $0.5 billion in 2008. 
                                                 
1  For instance, Standard Chartered Bank announced on 25 September 2018 that it had decided to end its financing of 
new  coal-fired  power  plants:  https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-stanchart-coal/stanchart-quits-lending-to-new-coal-
fired-power-stations-in-climate-change-effort-idUKKCN1M50I9 (last accessed 27 October 2018). 
2  Green bonds certified by the CBI to be complying with the CBS are called “climate bonds”. The key differences 
between the GBP and CBS are that the CBS requires external reviews (which the GBP recommends but not 
requires), and that climate bonds should be certified. Therefore, climate bonds are a subset of green bonds.

2 
5.  However, the issuance of green bonds has been concentrated in developed markets so 
far, with the exception of the People’s Republic of China and India. Issuance of green bonds by 
private sector issuers in most of the developing markets in Asia remains limited, mainly because 
the issuers are unfamiliar with the certification process and investors lack the experience. For 
instance, green bond issuance in the economies covered by the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN) accounted for only 5% of green bond issuance in all of Asia in the first half of 
2018. Further, many self-declared “green bonds” issued in Asia to date are often considered not 
in line with international best practice by the experts. This calls for the (i) establishment of local 
private sector green bond markets in the region and (ii) issuance of demonstrational genuine 
green bonds by a credible issuer with an international certification and/or a confirmation from an 
experienced institution in this field.  
 
6.  ADB is well positioned to play this role through “One ADB” approach. First, from the 
regulatory side, ADB’s extensive engagement in capital market development in the region enables 
it to showcase innovative products and  bring in international best practice. Indeed,  ADB’s 
Southeast Asia Department provided technical assistance to help the ASEAN Capital Markets 
Forum establish the ASEAN Green Bond Standards, a regional standard based on the GBP.3 
Secondly, from the private sector side, ADB Private Sector Operations Department can help 
ensure the eligibility of the bonds as green bonds and/or climate bonds in accordance with the 
relevant principles and standards, by leveraging the experience and skills from closing the Tiwi 
and MakBan Geothermal Power Green Bonds Project in the Philippines.4 
 
7.  Against this backdrop of huge untapped markets and opportunities for ADB, green bond 
issuance in ASEAN economies is expected to accelerate. Thailand, in particular, has great 
potential for an active green bond market because it has a huge renewable energy potential, and 
its bond market is the largest among ASEAN bond markets. While Thailand’s energy production 
still  depends  heavily on fossil fuels and  although  renewable energy sources  are currently 
contributing only 9%, this is projected to increase to 15%–20% by 2036 under Thailand’s Power 
Development Plan, 2015–2036.5 This translates into additional renewable capacity of 3,500 to 
6,000 MW. The Thai bond market's annual issuance of long-term corporate bonds totaled B823 
billion in 2017. However, renewable energy projects to date have been mainly financed by banks. 
Notwithstanding its growing needs and huge potential, the country’s first green bond complying 
with GBP was only issued in June 2018, by a local bank. 
  
8.  B.Grimm is a leading energy company in Thailand with a growing presence in other 
ASEAN countries such as the Lao People’s Democratic Republic and Viet Nam, and has a proven 
relationship with ADB through an equity investment and loan administration,6 and a loan facility.7 
B.Grimm is transforming itself from a Thai-based local gas-fired independent power producer into 
a renewable-energy-focused developer with a regional presence. Following its successful initial 
public offering (IPO) and completion of the first solar power plants, it aims to champion itself as 
the market leader in renewable energy and green bond issuance in Thailand and the region. In 
the past, the company typically sought bank financing for its power plants at the project level. Now

that the successful IPO and the investment grade local rating have significantly improved its 
access to the capital markets, it also seeks opportunities to issue corporate bonds. ADB has 
identified B.Grimm as the ideal partner based on the positive experience from the existing 
projects, and also on the relationship ADB has built with the company and other key players in 
Thailand’s energy sector. 
 
9.  Project design. The project involves the issuance of corporate bonds for the construction 
and refinancing of 16 utility-scale solar power plants in Thailand. The total installed capacity of 
the 16 plants is 98.5 MW, of which 9 plants totaling 67.7 MW (Yanhee and Sakeo subprojects) 
are completed and operational, while 7 plants totaling 30.8 MW (War Veterans Organization and 
Agricultural Cooperatives subprojects) are under construction. The plant size ranges from 2.3 MW 
to 8 MW, and the plants have power purchase agreements with the Provincial Electricity Authority 
(PEA) and the Metropolitan Electricity Authority  (MEA) under Thailand’s Very Small Power 
Producer (VSPP) program. B.Grimm will issue corporate bonds to which ADB will subscribe. The 
repayment of the bonds will be made from B.Grimm’s overall cash flows. 
 
10.  ADB will facilitate that the  bonds will comply with the International Capital Markets 
Association GBP, and will also assist B.Grimm in obtaining certification of the bonds as climate 
bonds meeting the CBS by CBI. ADB will monitor whether B.Grimm upholds its commitment to 
continued compliance with the GBP and CBS.8 The key criteria for the bonds to be eligible as 
green  and  climate  bonds  are:  (i)  project  selection  and  nomination,  (ii) B.Grimm’s  internal 
processes and controls of funds raised by the bonds, (iii) B.Grimm’s internal reporting and 
controls associated with internal proceeds management and information, (iv) eligibility of the 
nominated projects and assets, and (v) reporting to ADB. 
 
11.  These will be the first GBP-compliant green bonds in Thailand issued by an energy 
company. They will also be the country's first climate bonds meeting the CBS once certified by 
CBI. Notwithstanding the growing interest among the issuers and investors, and  a rapidly 
increasing issuance amount globally, the green bond segment in Thailand is still in its infancy 
because local market players lack the requisite experience. The project will contribute to the 
development of the green bond market in Thailand by showcasing genuine green and climate 
bonds (i.e., in conformance with international best practice and certified) to local issuers and 
investors, and ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department plans to roll out a program to 
encourage other competent and trustworthy market players in different areas—such as energy, 
water, transport, and other infrastructure—to issue green bonds. 
 
12.  The project complements ADB’s existing equity investment in B.Grimm, which played an 
important role in attracting third-party investors and establishing confidence in the equity market. 
The project extends its assistance to the debt capital markets to showcase the company as the 
leading green bond issuer. B.Grimm has adopted and is implementing ADB’s environmental and 
social  safeguard  standards  through  ADB’s  equity  investment,  which  also  helps  boost  the 
credibility of the company’s commitment to the GBP and CBS, and creates competitive financing 
options for B.Grimm to expand its renewable energy portfolio. 
 
                                                 
8  ADB has engaged a consultant to independently audit the project’s compliance with the GBP and the CBS. The 
consultant will issue an assurance report to ADB, which represents conformity with the GBP, and will also be sufficient 
for climate bond certification by the CBI. ADB will confirm the green bond status based on the assurance report, 
while the CBI will issue a third-party certification. Consultant fees are funded by ADB’s Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department under ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Enhancing Readiness of ADB 
Developing Member Countries for Scaled-Up Climate Finance. Manila.

4 
13.  Borrower. B.Grimm, established in 1993 in Thailand, is an energy company that focuses 
on the development, financing, construction, and operation of greenfield power plants. B.Grimm 
is a part of the B.Grimm Group, Thailand’s oldest infrastructure and industrial group in operation, 
founded in 1878. The group is ultimately owned by Harald Link and his family, which has owned 
the company since its founding. Its well-diversified business interests cover energy, cooling, 
health care, transport, lifestyle, and real estate. B.Grimm underwent a successful IPO in June 
2017. Harald Link and his daughter Caroline Link jointly hold 68.4% of the shares in the company 
directly or indirectly. Other shareholders are ADB (4.7%) and public investors (26.9%). 
 
14.  B.Grimm is one of the largest private power producers by installed capacity among 
Thailand’s Small Power Producer (SPP) operators. It has 15 existing gas-fired cogeneration 
plants with a total installed capacity of 2,045 MW. All of B.Grimm’s SPP power plants are 
strategically located in five leading industrial estates with  a high concentration of blue chip 
industrial customers. Since 2015, B.Grimm has started diversifying into renewable energy and is 
currently operating 15 solar power plants under Thailand’s VSPP program, with a total installed 
capacity of 114 MW. It also has solar power plants of 30.8 MW under construction in Thailand, 
and  a  677  MW  pipeline  of  solar  projects  in  Viet  Nam.  [CONFIDENTIAL  INFORMATION 
DELETED]. 
 
15.  B.Grimm is listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand. It has a current market capitalization 
of about $2.3 billion.9 TRIS Rating gave B.Grimm a corporate credit rating of A/Stable in April 
2018. Table 1 summarizes B.Grimm’s historical financial performance.

B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
17.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: diversified energy mix through 
the addition of renewable energy capacity (footnote 5). 
 
18.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: sustained private sector solar 
power project operations in Thailand.11 
 
19.  Outputs. The outputs will be that solar power projects in Thailand have been constructed 
and are operational, and that the green and climate bond status has been achieved. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
20.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030, which has a target of 75% of ADB operations to support climate change 
mitigation and adaptation by 2030.12 Strategy 2030 also emphasizes the expansion of private 
sector operations. ADB’s support for the project is also in line with its country partnership strategy, 
2013–2016 for Thailand13 and its country operations business plan, 2018–2020,14 both of which 
promote private sector development and support two core strategic areas for ADB’s focus: 
infrastructure development and environmentally sustainable development. 
 
21.  Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  project  is 
consistent with ADB’s Energy Policy, which supports wider access to energy through investments 
in energy efficiency and renewable energy projects.15 The project will contribute to ADB’s target 
of $6 billion in annual financing for climate mitigation and adaptation by 2020, and catalyze further 
private sector resources in the clean energy segment.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE

A.  The Assistance 
 
26.  ADB will provide debt financing to B.Grimm in the form of corporate bonds of up to B5,000 
million (or its equivalent in United States dollars). ADB’s assistance will be deployed for the 
refinancing  of  B.Grimm’s  existing  solar  plants,  and  construction  of  its  new  solar  plants  in 
Thailand.18 The bonds comprise a 5-year bond of up to B1,500 million and a 7-year bond of up to 
B3,500 million, both with a bullet repayment. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED]. 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
27.  Catalytic impact. ADB’s participation in B.Grimm’s bond program includes assistance to 
ensure both that the bonds will comply with the GBP and obtain climate bond certification. 
Association with ADB will also help make the GBP and climate bonds better known in the region. 
Such instruments and standards are not yet well-recognized in the Thai and ASEAN capital 
markets, and local or regional bond investors and issuers do not yet have the requisite expertise 
or experience to establish green bond status or third-party certification. The successful issuance 
of these bonds with ADB’s confirmation as green bonds and climate bond certification by CBI will 
foster confidence among issuers as they see the benefits associated with green bonds (franchise 
value enhancement, industry leadership, reputation enhancement, integration of sustainable 
principles and greenhouse gas emissions reduction into the strategy) and help promote further 
investments in renewable energy and other climate-friendly businesses. Overall, this will channel 
more funding into, or enable easier access to funding for, renewable energy and other climate-
friendly projects. Further, B.Grimm’s environmental and social management system (ESMS), 
which exceeds national standards, will become widely known and put other players in the market 
under more pressure to catch up in this respect. 
 
28.  Green bond program. With the proposed project, ADB will potentially kickstart a program 
for green bond issuance by the private sector, which will mobilize additional commercial investors 
and issuers into this emerging asset class. By leveraging its regional presence, ADB will replicate 
green bond issuance in accordance with international best practice in Thailand and in other 
ASEAN economies, with possible effects on other bond markets in Asia.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
29.  ADB categorized the investment in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009)  as  follows:  environment  (category  B),  involuntary  resettlement  (category  C),  and 
indigenous peoples (category C).19 Its Safeguard Policy Statement Safeguard Requirements 4 
for general corporate finance project applies. 
 
30.  ADB undertook due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social impacts 
of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse

impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. The environmental and social measures and the 
institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  B.Grimm  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and 
environmental impacts are deemed adequate. The operational subprojects are assets to which 
the  proceeds  of  ADB’s  previously  approved  equity  investment  were  applied  in  2017.  The 
corporate ESMS audit that was undertaken while processing the earlier investment applies to this 
project (footnote 6). An audit of selective assets was also undertaken at the time which covered 
the operational subprojects. Corrective actions to address the findings of that corporate audit and 
ensure  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  were  fully  carried  out  and 
incorporated in B.Grimm’s ESMS prior to ADB’s equity subscription in 2017. It was agreed that 
the ESMS be implemented for all subprojects that utilize ADB’s debt and equity financing, and 
will be applied on a best-effort basis for non-ADB funded subprojects. 
 
31.  Environment. An existing facilities audit was undertaken by an external party to assess 
the subprojects’ compliance with B.Grimm’s ESMS and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
Safeguard Requirements 1–3. The audit reviewed all the subprojects with a focus on the seven 
subprojects under construction that are nearly completed, with scheduled commercial operation 
dates in December 2018. B.Grimm has advised that flooding studies were completed for each 
site and that the results were factored into the technical design. A review of the local environment 
reports found some gaps in biodiversity assessment and climate risk assessment conducted for 
the subprojects. Three of the subprojects are in the lower portion of the Central Basin Important 
Bird  Area,  which  is  a  wintering  area  for  the  Manchurian  Reed-warbler  (VU).20 The  three 
subprojects were developed on former agricultural lands and are not in legally protected areas. 
The  photovoltaic  panels  have  anti-glare  surfaces  with  row  separation  minimizing  risks  to 
birds. The  subprojects  are  located  no  more  than  approximately  fifty  meters  from  existing 
transmission lines. Although the project sites are not likely to have a significant impact on the 
species since they have an average size of 7.8 hectares—compared with a total important bird 
area of 190,000 hectares—additional studies and actions will be required. The audit also found 
opportunities for improving occupational health and safety, enforcement of the local labor code, 
grievance redress mechanism record keeping, and environmental monitoring record keeping. 
B.Grimm has committed to implement a corrective action plan to fill the gaps identified by the 
audit, including (i) biodiversity assessment for the three sites, (ii) measures to maintain or restore 
the Manchurian Reed-warbler habitat within the green areas of those sites, (iii) occupational 
health and safety improvements, and record-keeping improvements applicable for all subprojects. 
 
32.  Social safeguards. Land for subprojects in operation or under construction for which ADB 
proceeds will be used were purchased through negotiated settlements with individual landowners 
on mutually agreed terms. No outstanding legacy issues pertaining to land for the subprojects 
were found. The subprojects are in areas where typically no distinct or vulnerable ethnic minority 
groups reside who could be adversely or beneficially affected. Therefore, involuntary resettlement 
and/or indigenous people issues are not envisaged for the project. 
 
33.  Other social dimensions. The project is classified as having no gender elements.21 
B.Grimm will (i) apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list and (ii) ensure that investments

International in 2016. 
21 During due diligence, gender assessment of B.Grimm’s human resource and corporate social responsibility 
approaches was conducted. Given that (i) ADB’s financing will be channeled to completed and close-to-complete 
solar subprojects which have low staffing requirements; and (ii) at the corporate level, 44% of B.Grimm’s Board of 
Directors are female, its company president is female, and 47% of its headquarter staff are female, no gender 
elements for this transaction is pursued. However, B.Grimm has agreed to continue to explore and implement other

9 
using ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by national laws and 
regulations. The ESMS sets out requirements, as applicable, for compliance with national labor 
laws and measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant 
to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy (2001).22 The ESMS will also contain requirements, as 
applicable, for information disclosure and consultation with affected people in line with ADB 
standards. B.Grimm will report regularly to ADB on (i) its and its investments’ compliance with 
such laws and (ii) the measures taken.23 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
34.  B.Grimm was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
35.  The proposed debt investment is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and 
single exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
36.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),24 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance  upon establishing that  the Government of 
Thailand has no objection to the proposed assistance to B.Grimm Power Public Company Limited. 
ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, 
following approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
37.  I am satisfied that the proposed  debt investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
proposed debt investment in bonds of up to B5,000,000,000 (or its equivalent in United States 
dollars) from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to be issued by B.Grimm Power Public Company 
Limited for the Thailand Green Bond Project in Thailand, with such terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.
